column2:
COVID-19 negative certification required for entering the country. *If you’re fully vaccinated you must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding your flight or a negative antigen test taken within 48 hours before boarding your flight. If you are a child under 6, an airline crew member transiting the country through an international airport for less than 24 hours, have had coronavirus within 90 days of your trip, or a resident of a neighbouring country, or you have spent the last 14 days in a neighbouring country, you are exempt from this requirement.
If you’re a resident of Argentina and you’re fully vaccinated:
• You must have received a complete course of a vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival into Argentina.
• You must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling con-firming you will abide by COVID-19 restrictions;
*If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 in the past 90 days, and you are a resident of Argentina, you are allowed to enter the country and you will not need to take an additional COVID-19 test. The evidence you will need to present will depend on whether you were diagnosed with a lab test or without one:
*Residents of Argentina: If you’re a resident of Argentina and you’re not fully vaccinated:
• You must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding your flight, or a negative antigen test taken within 48 hours before boarding your flight. Land border travellers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of starting their journey, or an antigen test taken within 48 hours of starting their journey, no older than 7 days. The following are exempt of this requirement: Children under 6, airline crew members transiting the country through an international air-port for less than 24 hours, travellers who have had coronavirus within 90 days of their trip or who have spent the last 14 days in a neighbouring country.
• If you have had COVID-19 confirmed by a lab test within 90 days of your trip you don’t need to take a PCR test. I
column3:
Self-isolation at own accommodation- subject to testing. *If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Argentina as a tourist without needing quarantine. At least 14 days must have passed since your second dose of the vaccine. Children who do not qualify as fully vaccinated can enter Argentina without needing to self-isolate but should avoid large gatherings for the first 7 days.
*If you have tested positive for COVID-19, you can enter the country on a private vehicle after a 7-day self-isolation period, counting from the day the lab test was taken or from the day the symptoms started. You can enter the country on passenger directed vehicles after a 10-day self-isolation period, counting from the day the lab test was taken or from the day the symptoms started.
*Non-resident foreign nationals who are not fully vaccinated cannot enter Argentina for tourism purposes. If you would like to request for an exemption, you must contact your nearest Argentine Consulate to seek approval for your trip. You ust self-isolate for 7 days counting from the day after the PCR or antigen test was taken.
column4:
As of 31 December, Argentina’s borders are open to all travellers who meet the following requirements:
• Must have received a complete course of a vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival into Argentina
• Must be able to prove full vaccination status via the App Mi Argentina, or via a document from a national or state-level public health body if vaccinated abroad
• Must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling
column5:
Latest News:

International Restrictions:
*If you’re fully vaccinated: If you’re fully vaccinated, you can enter Argentina as a tourist without needing quarantine. At least 14 days must have passed since your second dose of the vaccine. Whether you have received a complete course of a vaccine or not, will be determined by the authorities of the country where you received your vaccine. You must be able to prove your full vaccination status via a document from a national or state-level public health body if vaccinated abroad.
You must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling confirming you will abide by COVID-19 restrictions.
You must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding your flight or a negative antigen test taken within 48 hours before boarding your flight. If you are a child under 6, an airline crew member transiting the country through an international airport for less than 24 hours, have had coronavirus within 90 days of your trip, or a resident of a neighbouring country, or you have spent the last 14 days in a neighbouring country, you are exempt from this requirement. If you have had COVID-19 confirmed by a lab test within 90 days of your trip, you don’t need to take a PCR test. Instead, you will need to show evidence of your diagnosis and a medical certificate issued at least 10 days after being diagnosed confirming that you have a clean bill of health; If you have been diagnosed without a lab test, due to a close contact with a positive case within 90 days of starting your trip, you will need to show a medical certificate issued at least 10 days after your symptoms started or of the close contact with a positive case, confirming that you have a clean bill of health.
You must have medical insurance with comprehensive cover for coronavirus, including hospitalisation and the costs of self-isolation and medical transport services for positive and suspected cases, as well as for close contacts. All travellers must be prepared to show proof of having complied with all entry requirements when required by the authorities during their first 14 days in the country.
Children who do not qualify as fully vaccinated can enter Argentina without needing to self-isolate but should avoid large gatherings for the first 7 days.
Proof of vaccination status: You must present proof that you have been fully vaccinated to enter Argentina for tourism purposes.
Argentina will accept proof of COVID-19 recovery and vaccination record and proof of COVID-19 vaccination issued in the Crown Dependencies. Your second dose must have been administered at least 14 days prior to travel. Your appointment card from vaccination centres is not designed to be used as proof of vaccination and should not be used to demonstrate your vaccine status.
*Residents of Argentina: If you’re a resident of Argentina and you’re fully vaccinated:
• You must have received a complete course of a vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival into Argentina. Whether you have received a complete course of a vaccine or not, will be determined by the authorities of the country where you received your vaccine
• You must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling con-firming you will abide by COVID-19 restrictions;
• If you have tested positive for COVID-19, you can enter the country on a private vehicle after a 7-day self-isolation period, counting from the day the lab test was taken or from the day the symptoms started. You can enter the country on passenger directed vehicles after a 10-day self-isolation period, counting from the day the lab test was taken or from the day the symptoms started
• If you are a close contact of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, you can enter the country on a private vehicle as long as you have not developed symptoms
*If you’re not fully vaccinated: If you’re not fully vaccinated, and you’re not a resident of Argentina, you cannot enter the country for tourism purposes. Whether you have received a complete course of a vaccine or not, will be determined by the authorities of the country where you received your vaccine.
*If you’ve had COVID-19 in the last 90 days: If you’re not fully vaccinated but have tested positive for COVID-19 in the past 90 days, and you are a resident of Argentina, you are allowed to enter the country and you will not need to take an additional COVID-19 test. The evidence you will need to present will depend on whether you were diagnosed with a lab test or without one:
• If you have had COVID-19 confirmed by a lab test within 90 days of your trip you don’t need to take a PCR test. Instead, you will need to show evidence of your diagnosis and a medical certificate issued at least 10 days after being diagnosed, confirming that you have a clean bill of health
• If you have been diagnosed without a lab test, due to a close contact with a positive case within 90 days of starting your trip, you will need to show a medical certificate is-sued at least 10 days after your symptoms started or of the close contact with a positive case, confirming that you have a clean bill of health
You can use proof of COVID-19 recovery record to demonstrate proof of COVID-19 recovery when entering Argentina.
*Residents of Argentina: If you’re a resident of Argentina and you’re not fully vaccinated:
• You must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding your flight, or a negative antigen test taken within 48 hours before boarding your flight. Land border travellers must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours of starting their journey, or an antigen test taken within 48 hours of starting their journey, no older than 7 days. The following are exempt of this requirement: Children under 6, airline crew members transiting the country through an international air-port for less than 24 hours, travellers who have had coronavirus within 90 days of their trip or who have spent the last 14 days in a neighbouring country.
• If you have had COVID-19 confirmed by a lab test within 90 days of your trip you don’t need to take a PCR test. Instead, you will need to show evidence of your diagnosis and a medical certificate issued at least 10 days after being diagnosed, confirming that you have a clean bill of health. If you have been diagnosed without a lab test, due to a close contact with a positive case within 90 days of starting your trip, you will need to show a medical certificate issued at least 10 days after your symptoms started or of the close contact with a positive case, confirming that you have a clean bill of health
• You must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling
• You must self-isolate for 7 days counting from the day after the PCR or antigen test was taken;
• Children aged 17 or under do not have to self-isolate but should avoid large gatherings for the first 7 days
• You can enter the country on a private vehicle if you are a close contact of someone who has tested positive for COVID-19, as long as you have not developed symptoms, and must self-isolate for 10 days after your most recent contact
*Children and young people: Children aged 5 and under, do not need to take a test to enter Argentina. Children aged 17 and under who do not qualify as fully vaccinated can enter Argentina without needing to self-isolate but should avoid large gatherings for the first 7 days.
*Transiting through Argentina: If you are transiting through Argentina on your way to another country and staying in the airport (airside) you are not required to comply with any sanitary requirements.
If you are transiting through Argentina on your way to another country and will be passing through immigration (sometimes known as a layover), for example to stay in a hotel for a flight the next day, you must comply with the sanitary entry requirements applicable to you. These will differ if you are a non-resident foreign national or a resident of Argentina, as well as if you are fully vaccinated, or not.
*Exemptions: Non-resident foreign nationals who are not fully vaccinated cannot enter Argentina for tourism purposes. If you would like to request for an exemption, you must contact your nearest Argentine Consulate to seek approval for your trip.
• If the exemption is granted, you will have to comply with the following requirements: You must present an official document proving the exemption was granted;
• You must present a negative COVID-19 PCR test taken within 72 hours before boarding your flight or a negative antigen test taken within 48 hours before boarding your flight;
• Must fill in an electronic ‘sworn statement’ form within 48 hours of travelling;
• Must self-isolate for 7 days counting from the day after the PCR or antigen test was taken;
• You must have medical insurance with comprehensive cover for coronavirus, including hospitalisation and the costs of self-isolation and medical transport services for positive and suspected cases, as well as for close contacts


Internal Restrictions:
*Travel in Argentina: Free movement is allowed within each jurisdiction as long as social distancing rules are adhered to.
If you are aged 13 or over you may be required to prove you have received a complete course of a COVID-19 vaccine to enter certain venues and events. You can do this via the ‘Cuidar’ (Health Pass) app, or via a document from a national or state-level public health body if vaccinated abroad. Additional requirements can be imposed by each jurisdiction/province.
Movement between jurisdictions is permitted, provided you meet the requirements of the specific jurisdiction/province you plan to visit.
You should make sure you understand and comply with the measures in place in the province/jurisdiction you are in. You should check what measures apply in your location and any other location you might qualify to travel to or transit through on the Ministry of Health website (in Spanish). You could be subject to a financial penalty if you do not abide by local regulations.
Public spaces and services: Social distancing of 2m is mandatory throughout Argentina.
In all parts of the country you must cover your nose and mouth with a face mask or other garment in shared spaces, both indoors and outdoors. You may only remove your face mask outside as long as you keep a 2m distance between yourself and other people.
Additional restrictions may vary between jurisdictions. Make sure to check what rules apply in your jurisdiction.
column6: US State Dept. COVID-19 Country Specific Information/ Foreign travel advice, Gov.UK/ Health Ministry/
